content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like it. Surprisingly, regular expressions can be useful here.

Hi, it seems to me that there is a lack of some rule on the minimum repetitions,
for example:
it is needed to manage also 0.23 as input ? and in that case it means 0.232323... or 0.23333... ?
and also 0.129876987 ? (not shown the complete second repetition of 9876)
or 1.41114111 ? means 1.4111411111111111 or 1.4111411141114111411 ?

if I were you, I would specify that the input always has at least one (or two?) full repetition of the periodic portion

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It works fine and it was fun doing it.

The tests/validators are missing the case where a digit of the period is also present in the non-repeating part, for examples:
0.21424242424  => 707 / 3300
0.06106610661066 => 3053 / 49995

Your current code times out with these examples.

The tests/validators are missing the case where the period contains the same digit multiple times:
0.73393393393  => 1222 / 1665
0.14114114114 => 47 / 333

Your current code is finding a wrong result with these examples.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: good game

You could add decimals whith a period that is greater or equal than 1:
Example: if x=0.67676767... it has a period of 2, and with a simple trick, you can find that x=67/99

Cheers
Recurring decimal is unfortunately similar to the title of other existing puzzle https://www.codingame.com/ide/puzzle/recurring-decimals

Title
* Based on wikipedia, the term should be "repeating decimal" or "recurring decimal" instead of "periodic decimal".
(Ref: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Repeating_decimal)

Goal section
* "an rational number" should be changed to "a rational number".

* The output may be a fraction or an integer. That should be mentioned here too.

* More explanation is required.

Input section
* Please delete ", we don't know the length of the string."

* Please change "string" to "float".

Output section
* Please change "A int number" to "An integer".

Constraints section
* Please mention that the number is always positive.

Cases
* Please fix the following titles:
  • "différente" (2 times): Use English please.
  • "begining" should be changed to "beginning".
  • "int" should be changed to "integer".
  • "whit": Do you mean "with"?

* As I mentioned above, you have to add more explanation for the cases to make sense.
For example, if I treat 0.333333333333333 as a non-recurring decimal (which is also a "rational number"), the answer would be 333333333333333 / 1000000000000000.

Stub generator
* Please add a write statement (e.g. "write answer").

Thanks.
At least this time the conversion is the other way round, so it should be ok.
Thank you ! It's a good idea I just changed that !
Yes, I agree with you, however I want an affordable problem and I wanted to propose a more complicated problem in episode 2 if this one is validated.

Thank you for making the changes. Below are some new comments based on the revised version.

Goal section
* Please change the first sentence as:
Convert any given recurring decimal to an irreducible fraction or an integer of equivalent amount.

Input section
* Please add "for the recurring decimal to be converted".

Output section
* Please add "if the result is an irreducible fraction" to the end of Case 1.

* Please add "otherwise" to the end of Case 2.

Constraints section
* Please mention that the number is always positive.

Cases
* Please remove the two cases where the decimals end in ".0", because those cases do NOT involve any recurring decimal. You have copied the definition from Wiki to Goal section, and it does state that "the infinitely repeated portion is not zero".

Thanks.
